deliberation: I checked for idiomatic or metaphorical uses (e.g., 'all the words of YHWH,' 'sent him to them'). The verse is a straightforward narrative formula introducing Jeremiah's speech; 'words' and 'sending' are standard ways to describe divine revelation and carry no special figurative twist here beyond normal communication language.

I considered whether 'you are lying' or the prohibition 'do not go to Egypt to sojourn there' contains figurative language. These are literal accusations and commands. No metaphor, simile, idiom, or metonymy appears.

I examined 'inciting you against us' and especially 'to give us into the hand of the Chaldeans.' The latter is the standard biblical idiom נתן/מסר ביד with 'hand' as metonymy for power/control. This is a clear figurative expression; the rest of the verse is literal.

theological reading of enemy power as a fate to be delivered into
instances.explanation: The idiom 'give into the hand of X' uses 'hand' as a metonymy for power and control, describing subjugation as if people were physically placed into an enemy’s hand.

deliberation: The key phrase is 'did not obey the voice of YHWH' (לֹא־שָׁמַע ... בְקוֹל יְהוָה). Literally it is 'did not listen to the voice of YHWH.' This is a fixed covenant idiom where 'voice' stands metonymically for God's command and 'listening' stands for obeying.

instances.english_text: did not obey GOD’s command (lit. 'did not listen to the voice of YHWH')
target: Johanan, the officers, and the people’s refusal to follow God's instruction
vehicle: a failed act of auditory attention
ground: ignoring someone's voice parallels ignoring their will
failure of attentive listening maps to refusal to comply
hearing as prerequisite for obedience
posture: evaluates their action as stubborn refusal of divine authority
frames disobedience in relational/auditory terms
covenant lawsuit style depiction of guilt
instances.explanation: The idiom 'not listen to the voice of YHWH' uses 'voice' metonymically for God's command and 'listening' for obedience, turning an auditory image into a moral-theological assessment.

deliberation: I considered 'the entire remnant of Judah' (שְׁאֵרִית יְהוּדָה) and 'from all the nations where they had been driven.' 'Remnant' here literally denotes the surviving subset; it is a theological theme but not used as part-for-whole synecdoche. 'Driven' is standard exile language but functions here as a literal description of forced displacement. No clear, discrete figurative device stands out.

The verse is a detailed list of groups taken to Egypt. I checked phrases like 'all the people whom Nebuzaradan left with Gedaliah' for idioms or metaphors, but they are straightforward narrative references to historical actors and groups.

Again the phrase 'they did not obey GOD' reflects the Hebrew idiom 'they did not listen to the voice of YHWH' (לֹא שָׁמְעוּ בְּקוֹל יְהוָה). As in verse 4, this is an idiomatic, metonymic expression for covenant disobedience.

instances.english_text: They did not obey GOD (lit. 'they did not listen to the voice of YHWH')
target: the people's refusal to follow God’s instruction by going to Egypt
ground: refusal to heed a voice parallels refusal to accept authority

supports the prophetic accusation of rebellion
instances.explanation: The fixed phrase 'not listen to the voice of YHWH' uses 'voice' metonymically for command and has become an idiom meaning 'to disobey,' casting their movement to Egypt as covenant rebellion.

deliberation: The formula 'the word of YHWH came to Jeremiah' (וַיְהִי דְבַר־יְהוָה אֶל־יִרְמְיָהוּ) depicts 'word' as an entity that can 'come' to someone. This personifies the divine message and also uses 'word' metonymically for God’s act of speaking/revealing.

treating the message as an arriving agent highlights its initiative

instances.explanation: The phrase personifies the 'word' as an agent that 'comes' and uses 'word' metonymically for God's act of speaking, picturing revelation as an active arrival rather than a mere inner idea.

deliberation: This verse prescribes a symbolic act (taking stones and embedding them in mortar), but linguistically it is described in literal, concrete terms. The symbolic meaning is given in the next verse; here there is no metaphorical wording—just instructions about actual stones, mortar, and location.

I examined: (1) the designation of Nebuchadrezzar as 'my servant' and (2) the setting of his throne and pavilion over the stones. The enthronement language over stones can be read literally as a prophetic sign of his future presence; it is not necessarily a figurative phrase. However, calling a pagan king 'my servant' for YHWH is a clear role metaphor: he is not literally YHWH’s worshiping servant, but an instrument used for YHWH’s purposes.

instances.explanation: Calling Nebuchadrezzar 'my servant' metaphorically casts him as YHWH’s subordinate agent, emphasizing that his military actions function in service of God’s purposes rather than his own autonomous power.

deliberation: I considered the triad 'those to death, to death; to captivity, to captivity; to the sword, to the sword.' The form itself is emphatic but not figurative. However, 'the sword' is a standard metonymy for warfare/violent death. The phrase 'those destined for the sword, to the sword' uses the instrument ('sword') for the manner of death.

instances.explanation: Here 'the sword' stands metonymically for violent death in battle; the instrument is used to evoke the whole experience and outcome of warfare.

deliberation: I examined 'I will set fire to the temples' (literal destructive language) and especially 'he shall wrap [himself in] the land of Egypt as a shepherd wraps his garment.' This is an explicit simile (כַּאֲשֶׁר), picturing Nebuchadrezzar’s appropriation of Egypt in terms of a shepherd easily wrapping his cloak.

deliberation: I checked whether 'the obelisks of the House of the Sun' or 'burn the temples of the gods of Egypt' are figurative. These refer to literal cultic structures in Egypt and literal acts of smashing and burning. The name 'House of the Sun' functions as a proper noun; the description itself is not used figuratively.
